key_concepts.description: Fire generates heat causing air to rise, creating convective flow patterns
key_concepts.equations: Boussinesq approximation: ρ = ρ₀(1 - β(T - T₀))
key_concepts.relevance: Critical for modeling plume rise and fire behavior on slopes
key_concepts.implementation: Add buoyancy term to spread calculations based on temperature gradient

key_concepts.description: Fire-induced turbulence enhances oxygen mixing and combustion
key_concepts.equations: k-ε turbulence model or Large Eddy Simulation (LES)
key_concepts.relevance: Affects fire intensity and rate of spread
key_concepts.implementation: Incorporate turbulence factor based on fire intensity and wind speed

key_concepts.description: Vorticity generation from buoyancy and wind shear creates rotating fire columns
key_concepts.relevance: Can cause extreme fire behavior and long-range spotting
key_concepts.implementation: Add vorticity threshold for fire whirl formation under high wind + intense fire

key_concepts.description: Fire plume entrains ambient air, diluting smoke and affecting combustion
key_concepts.relevance: Affects plume height and oxygen availability
key_concepts.implementation: Model oxygen depletion in high-intensity fires

key_concepts.description: Fire emits thermal radiation affecting unburned fuel ahead of fire front
key_concepts.implementation: Add radiation factor to ROSf based on fire intensity

topics.name: Climate Change, Precipitation, and Fire Behavior

key_concepts.description: BUI = f(DMC, DC) increases with longer dry periods under climate change
key_concepts.trends: Projected 10-30% increase by 2050 in boreal regions
key_concepts.relevance: Higher BUI = deeper burning, higher intensity, more difficult suppression
key_concepts.implementation: Add climate adjustment factor: BUI_adjusted = BUI × (1 + 0.002 × years_since_2020)

key_concepts.description: Climate change shifts precipitation: fewer events, higher intensity
key_concepts.impact: Short intense rain does not reduce DC as much as prolonged gentle rain
key_concepts.relevance: Drought Code accumulation accelerates despite unchanged total precipitation
key_concepts.implementation: Weight DC reduction by precipitation duration, not just amount

key_concepts.description: Heavy fuels (DC, DMC) respond slowly to precipitation
key_concepts.timescales: FFMC: hours, DMC: days, DC: weeks
key_concepts.relevance: Single rain event may reduce FFMC but not DC
key_concepts.implementation: Exponential decay: DC_new = DC_old × exp(-P/τ), τ = 52 days

key_concepts.description: Warmer temperatures increase evapotranspiration, drying fuels faster
key_concepts.effect: Net drying even if precipitation unchanged
key_concepts.implementation: Temperature correction: DC_change += α × (T - T_ref), α = 2.0

key_concepts.description: Hot-dry-windy days cluster more frequently under climate change
key_concepts.statistics: Frequency of FWI > 30 days projected to double by 2050
key_concepts.relevance: More days with extreme fire potential
key_concepts.implementation: Track multi-day heat waves and adjust fire risk accordingly

relevant_papers.relevance: Quantifies historical and projected fire weather changes

relevant_papers.title: Drought code projections for North America
relevant_papers.key_finding: DC > 400 days projected to increase 50-100% by 2100

relevant_papers.title: Precipitation intensity and fuel moisture dynamics
relevant_papers.key_finding: Precipitation distribution matters more than total amount
relevant_papers.relevance: Explains why total precipitation can be unchanged but fire risk increases
